Question_1.Context: In the study, what was the main focus regarding the development of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives?
Question_1.Question: What is the main focus of developing radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives in the study?
Question_1.B: Improving stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_1.C: Enhancing cellular uptake in tumor-bearing mice
Question_1.D: Increasing the biodistribution in various organs
Question_1.Source: However, 211At-labeled amino acid derivatives exhibit instability against deastatination in vivo, making it challenging to use 211At for radiotherapy.

Question_2.Context: What was the significance of introducing the neopentyl glycol (NpG) structure into the phenolic hydroxyl group of L-tyrosine?
Question_2.Question: Why was it significant to introduce the neopentyl glycol (NpG) structure into the phenolic hydroxyl group of L-tyrosine?
Question_2.A: To enhance stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_2.B: To increase cellular uptake in tumor cells
Question_2.C: To improve biodistribution in various organs
Question_2.D: To target a specific amino acid transporter
Question_2.Source: These results indicate that NpG can effectively retain radiohalogens such as 211At, even when labeling low-molecular-weight compounds such as L-tyrosine.

Question_3.Context: What was the rationale behind designing radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives with the NpG structure?
Question_3.Question: Why were radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives designed with the NpG structure?
Question_3.A: To enhance cellular uptake in tumor-bearing mice
Question_3.B: To improve stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_3.C: To increase the biodistribution in various organs
Question_3.D: To target a specific amino acid transporter
Question_3.Source: Based on these findings, we designed an NpG-conjugated L-tyrosine by introducing the NpG structure into the hydroxyl group of the phenol in L-tyrosine.

Question_4.Context: What was the main similarity observed between [211At]At-NpGT and [18F]F-NpGT in the study?
Question_4.Question: What was the main similarity observed between [211At]At-NpGT and [18F]F-NpGT?
Question_4.A: Similar cellular uptake in tumor cells
Question_4.B: High stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_4.D: Effective inhibition of tumor growth in mice
Question_4.Source: In particular, the similarity in the biodistribution of [211At]At-NpGT and [18F]F-NpGT indicates that this pair of radiolabeled compounds would be useful for radiotheranostics.

Question_5.Context: What was the effect of [211At]At-NpGT on the growth of glioma-bearing mice?
Question_5.Question: What effect did [211At]At-NpGT have on the growth of glioma-bearing mice?
Question_5.C: Dose-dependent inhibitory effect on tumor growth
Question_5.Source: [211At]At-NpGT exhibited a dose-dependent inhibitory effect on the growth of glioma-bearing mice.

Question_6.Context: What was the main reason for the high accumulation of [211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT in the kidney and pancreas?
Question_6.Question: Why did [211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT show high accumulation in the kidney and pancreas?
Question_6.C: Low stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_6.D: High affinity for LAT1 in these tissues
Question_6.Source: These results suggest that, although the calculated molecular weights of these compounds were significantly different, these radiolabeled compounds were similarly recognized by LAT1.

Question_7.Context: What was the significance of the rapid blood clearance observed for [211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT?
Question_7.Question: Why was the rapid blood clearance observed for [211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT significant?
Question_7.A: Enhanced stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_7.D: Prolonged residence time in the bloodstream
Question_7.Source: Nonetheless, the rapid clearance of these radiolabeled compounds from the bloodstream has enabled the attainment of high tumor-to-blood ratios.

Question_8.Context: What was the main observation regarding the excretion of radioactivity from tumor cells incorporating [125I]I-NpGT?
Question_8.Question: What was the main observation regarding the excretion of radioactivity from tumor cells incorporating [125I]I-NpGT?
Question_8.C: Accumulation in tumor cells over time
Question_8.Source: The main radioactivity was derived from intact [125I]I-NpGT, supporting high stability against dehalogenation in vivo.

Question_9.Context: What was the rationale behind the design of [211At]At-NpGT for therapeutic applications?
Question_9.Question: Why was [211At]At-NpGT designed for therapeutic applications?
Question_9.A: To enhance cellular uptake in tumor cells
Question_9.B: To improve stability against dehalogenation in vivo
Question_9.C: To increase the biodistribution in various organs
Question_9.D: To target a specific amino acid transporter
Question_9.Source: Since accumulation in the liver has also been observed for [18F]-FMT, this observation in our compounds was thought to be due to the introduction of substituents to the hydroxyl group of phenol in L-tyrosine.

Question_10.Context: What was the main finding regarding the therapeutic effect of [211At]At-NpGT on tumor growth?
Question_10.Question: What was the main finding regarding the therapeutic effect of [211At]At-NpGT on tumor growth?
Question_10.C: Dose-dependent inhibitory effect on tumor growth
Question_10.Source: [211At]At-NpGT significantly inhibited tumor growth in a dose-dependent manner compared to control mice.
